document.docAuthor: Rueda Martín, Paola A., Gibon, Francois-Marie & Sganga, Julieta V.
document.masterDocTitle: New species and records of the Neotropical genus Cyrnellus (Trichoptera: Polycentropodidae) and the re-establishment of C. minimus and C. marginalis

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New species and records of the Neotropical genus Cyrnellus (Trichoptera: Polycentropodidae) and the re-establishment of C. minimus and C. marginalis

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Instituto de Biodiversidad Neotropical, CONICET Facultad de Ciencias Naturales e Instituto Miguel Lillo, Miguel Lillo 205, San Miguel de Tucumán, Tucumán, Argentina
CBGP, IRD, CIRAD, INRAE, Montpellier SupAgro, Univ. Montpellier, Montpellier, France.
Departamento de Biodiversidad y Biología Experimental, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales (UBA). CABA, Argentina. jsganga @ gmail. com; https: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0003 - 1210 - 5937

heading.emphasis:
Key to adult males of the genus
Cyrnellus

paragraph.keyLead:
2(1). Posterior margins of sternite IX convex and sinuous with slight undulations; subapicomesal spine I closer to apex of each inferior appendage and digitate ( Figs 6A–6D , as )....................................................
C. misionensis

- Posterior margins of sternite IX irregular with some excisions and protuberances ( Fig. 5A ); subapicomesal spine I of each inferior appendage in mesal or subapical position ( Fig. 5B , as )................................................. 3

3(2). Subapicomesal spine I of each inferior appendage mesally inserted, long and digitate ( Figs 4E–4H )..............
C. rianus

- Subapicomesal spine I, subapically inserted, short and triangular ( Figs 5A–5D )................................
C. risi
- Subapicomesal spine rounded or mammiform ( Figs 2F , 6F ), or with two subapicomesal points ( Figs 1B , 2B , 5F , 7B )...... 9

5(4). Subapicomesal spine of each inferior appendage arising far from apex ( Figs 3E–3K )......................
C. fraternus
- Subapicomesal spine arising close to apex ( Figs 1G , 3B , 4B )................................................... 6

6(5). Triangular subapicomesal spine of each inferior appendage flat ( Figs 1F–1I )............................
C. boliviensis
- Triangular subapicomesal spine circular in cross-section ( Figs 3B , 4B ).......................................... 7

7(6). Subapicomesal spine of each inferior appendage with wide base, forming equilateral triangle ( Figs 3A–3D )...
C. marginalis

8(7). Subapicomesal spine of each inferior appendage conspicuously subapical, inner lobe triangular ( Figs 4A–4D )....
C. minimus

- Subapicomesal spine very near apex, inner lobe round ( Chamorro-Lacayo 2003 , fig. 2B)................
C. zapateriensis

9(4). Subapicomesal spine II of each inferior appendage absent, single subapicomesal spine with wide, globular base ( Figs 2F , 6F ) .................................................................................................. 10

10(9). Posterior arms of dorsal phallic sclerite slender, sinuous, and divergent ( Figs 2E–2H )...................
C. mammillatus

- Posterior arms of dorsal phallic sclerite thick with heavily sclerotized apices ( Figs 6E–6H )...................
C. collaris

11(9). Subapicomesal spine I of each inferior appendage very near apex ( Figs 7A–7D )............................
C. bifidus

- Subapicomesal spine I conspicuously preapical, with variable distance between spine and apex of inferior appendage ( Figs 1B , 2B , 5F )............................................................................................ 12
- Dorsal phallic sclerite simple or indistinct ( Figs 2C , 5H ), with anterior arms reduced or absent...................... 13
